title: August 2025 Recovery 1

labels.name: endgame-plan
labels.description: VS Code - Next release plan for endgame

body:
<!--
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
-->

- [x] Create a milestone `August 2025 Recovery 1` **@sandy081**
- [x] Bump the version number & run `npm i` to bump `package-lock.json` as well. Ensure there are no other `package-lock.json` changes. **@sandy081**
- [x] [🔖candidate issues](https://github.com/issues?q=org%3Amicrosoft%20is%3Aissue%20milestone%3A%22August%202025%20Recovery%201%22%20label%3Acandidate)
- [x] Assign candidate issues to the recovery milestone **team**
- [x] Review the `candidate` issues, and if they pass the review assign them to the recovery milestone **team**
- [x] All `candidate` fixes are peer reviewed and pushed to `main` and then cherry-picked into the release branch **team**
- [x] Initiate `insiders` build from `main`
- [x] Issues are tested in the `insiders` **team**
- [x] Build and manually release Insider from main branch for vscode.dev (if there were vscode.dev candidates)
  - [x] Issues are tested in the `insiders` **team**
- [x] Build `stable` for all platforms from release branch **@sandy081**
- [x] Issues are verified on `stable` build and the `verified` label is added **@sandy081**
- [x] Check `https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/compare/release/<x.y>` to ensure no other commits have been made in the release branch **@sandy081**
- [x] The `insiders` build with all candidate fixes needs to be in the wild for 24 hours before recovery release, unless explicitly approved by @kieferrm
- [x] Update the release notes and include a link to a query for the fixed issues **@ntrogh**
- [x] [Sanity Testing](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Sanity-Check)
  - [x] Windows 64 bit **@hediet** 
    - [x] System Installer
    - [x] User Installer
    - [x] Archive

    - [x] CLI

    - [x] User Installer

    - [x] CLI
  - [x] macOS Intel **owner**
    - [x] Archive
    - [ ] Universal Archive
    - [ ] Server
    - [ ] CLI
  - [x] macOS ARM64 **@justschen** 
    - [x] Archive

- [x] Publish website **@rzhao271**
- [x] Publish stable build **@sandy081**
- [x] (if there were vscode.dev candidates) Trigger the [vscode.dev Deploy pipeline](https://dev.azure.com/monacotools/Monaco/_build?definitionId=276) for `release/x.y` for the `prod` deployment target. **@sandy081**
  - [x] Request approval from another team member at the necessary step to deploy the vscode.dev build. **@sandy081**
- [x] Create an official release **@sandy081**
  - [x] Create a tag (make sure you pull the release branch first): `git tag <x.y.z> release/<x.y>`
  - [x] Push the tag: `git push origin <x.y.z>`
  - [x] Create a GitHub release: [Open the GitHub tags](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/tags), and click far right `... > Create Release`. Use the correct title and description from our release notes. [Example](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.81.1)
- [x] Close the milestone on [GitHub](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/milestones) **@sandy081**

title: Wrong code review
body:
Type: Bug # Issue Description When using Copilot's ask mode for code review, I attached the workspace's commit state to check for potential deadlocks in newly added code sections (which contain many lock operations). The model used was Claude 4.0. # Reproduction Steps 1. In the VS Code workspace, use Copilot ask mode and attach the commit state for code review. 2. Ask the model to check whether the newly added lock operations may cause deadlocks. 3. Claude 4.0 marks every new lock operation with a possible deadlock type, but these annotations are clearly incorrect. # Specific Problem - Claude 4.0 reports circular dependency deadlocks even after a lock is acquired and released, where no deadlock risk actually exists. - The deadlock type judgment is inaccurate, with many false positives, which affects the efficiency and accuracy of code review. # Expected Result - The model should analyze lock operations more accurately, reasonably judge deadlock risks, and reduce false positives. - Hope Microsoft can optimize the model's lock analysis capability and improve Copilot's code review quality. # Additional Information - OS: Linux - IDE: Visual Studio Code - The project involves many lock operations (such as mutexes, read-write locks, etc.) - Error example: The model still reports circular dependency deadlocks after the lock has been released --- # Key Code Snippets ## 1. Lock Operations When Adding Tasks (thread_pool.c) ```c pthread_mutex_lock(&server->connection_status_mutex[client_fd]); uint8_t client_fd_status = server->connection_status[client_fd]; pthread_mutex_unlock(&server->connection_status_mutex[client_fd]); client_task->client_fd_status = client_fd_status; new_task->function = function; new_task->arg = arg; new_task->next = NULL; pthread_mutex_lock(&pool->queue_mutex); // ...subsequent queue operations... ``` ## 2. Connection Status Array and Mutex Initialization (server.c) ```c server->connection_status = calloc(server->max_fd_count, sizeof(u_int8_t)); server->connection_status_mutex = malloc(sizeof(pthread_mutex_t) * server->max_fd_count); for (int i = 0; i < server->max_fd_count; i++) { pthread_mutex_init(&server->connection_status_mutex[i], NULL); } ``` ## 3. Lock Operations When Changing Connection Status (task_handle.c) ```c void record_client_fd_status_change(server_t *server, int client_fd) { pthread_mutex_lock(&server->connection_status_mutex[client_fd]); server->connection_status[client_fd]++; pthread_mutex_unlock(&server->connection_status_mutex[client_fd]); } ``` ## 4. Connection Status Check Before Task Processing (task_handle.c) ```c pthread_mutex_lock(&server->connection_status_mutex[client_fd]); int client_fd_status = server->connection_status[client_fd]; pthread_mutex_unlock(&server->connection_status_mutex[client_fd]); if (client_fd_status != task->client_fd_status) { log_debug("Client fd %d status changed, skipping task", client_fd); return; } ``` --- These code snippets show the acquisition, release, and usage scenarios of locks. All are standard mutex operations, with no circular dependencies or nested locks, so theoretically, deadlocks should not occur. These can be used to support the claim of false deadlock reports by the model. Extension version: 0.30.3 VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Linux x64 6.8.0-79-generic Modes:

title: Auto save onFocusChange does not work when editing via peeked editor
body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No - VS Code Version: 1.103.2 (user setup) - OS Version: Windows 11, WSLv2 Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS Steps to Reproduce: 1. In the top navigation bar, go to File -> Preferences -> Settings 2. Select onFocusChange under "Auto Save" 3. Create the two following files ```python # test.py def hello() -> None: print("Hello There!") ``` ```python # test2.py from .test import hello hello() ``` (It does not need to be written in python, I have tried using JavaScript as well) 2. Click the definition of `hello` and press Shift + F12 to open the peek editor, should look something like this: 3. Navigate to the `test2.py` via the right hand list of files in the peeking editor. 4. Edit the `test2.py` file within the peeking editor. 5. Close the peeking editor window using the X seen in the screenshot. Expected behavior The changes in `test2.py` is auto saved. Actual behavior The changes in `test2.py` is NOT auto saved.

title: Color swatch/picker does not appear in SVG style attributes after fill/stroke prop colon if there is no redundant trailing space

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

labels.name: editor-color-picker
labels.description: Editor color picker widget issues

body:
Type: Bug It looks like the logic to show the hex/rbg[a]() color swatch/picker is very picky about how the color is specified. title: vscode.diff preserveFocus parameter not working
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->

<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0
- OS Version: macOS 14.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a VS Code extension
2. Call `vscode.commands.executeCommand('vscode.diff', oldUri, newUri, title, { preserveFocus: true })`
3. Observe that the diff editor still gains focus despite `preserveFocus: true`

**Expected Behavior:**
The diff editor should open without gaining focus, keeping the current editor focused.

**Actual Behavior:**
The diff editor gains focus regardless of the `preserveFocus: true` parameter.

**Code Sample:**
```typescript
await vscode.commands.executeCommand(
  'vscode.diff',
  vscode.Uri.file('/path/to/old/file'),
  vscode.Uri.file('/path/to/new/file'),
  'My Diff View',
  {
    preserveFocus: true,  // This parameter seems to be ignored
  }
);
```

**Additional Context:**
- This issue affects extension development where we want to show diffs without interrupting user workflow
- Similar `preserveFocus` parameters work correctly in other VS Code APIs like `showTextDocument`
- Tested with extensions disabled - issue persists

**Workaround Attempted:**
Manually restoring focus after diff creation using `showTextDocument` with a timeout.

title: dispose of ref instead of object itself to avoid null objects.
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

This PR fixes an issue with scrolling in Copilot chats with many code blocks (100+). The behavior is that after scrolling up and down through the chat, some code blocks shrink to 0 height and the code is no longer visible. See the included video for an example:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/98af5b0a-6951-4bc3-b2dd-0f68c9fad906

---

### Root Cause
The problem came from how `CodeBlockModelCollection` was disposing models. It was calling `ref.object.dispose()`, which disposes the **underlying text model itself**. Instead, it should call `ref.dispose()`, which disposes the **reference** and releases it.  

By disposing the model directly, later code block components ended up with null/invalid models during virtualization cycles. That’s why editors collapsed or reported `content height = -1`.

---

### Fix
Replace calls to `ref.object.dispose()` with `ref.dispose()` in `delete()` and `clear()`. This properly disposes the reference, allowing models to remain valid and be reused when scrolling back.

---

### Testing
- Manually tested with an OSS build of VS Code and Copilot Chat, reproducing the bug with >100 code blocks. After the fix, blocks remain visible when scrolling.  
- Ran automated tests (`./scripts/test.sh`) with no regressions.  
- See fix example here:  

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d4425097-919a-4212-8d63-4890af7a6c57  

---

### Related
Fixes #266296  
Related telemetry issues: #240028, #248829, #255827

- Copilot Chat Extension Version:

- OS Version:windows 11 pro,version:24H2;wsl
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode):agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet):claude 4
- Logs:

Steps to Reproduce:
run in wsl.
When Copilot launches a Python service, it opens a terminal and runs the service within that terminal. Subsequently, Copilot attempts to test the service using curl, but it does not open a new terminal for curl. Instead, it runs curl within the same terminal. This causes the service to be killed, preventing curl from accessing it. The process repeats endlessly, creating an infinite loop. I prompted Copilot to open a new terminal for curl, but it still didn't work.

title: Speed up get_task_output?

labels.name: tasks
labels.description: Task system issues

labels.name: polish
labels.description: Cleanup and polish issue

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

body:
I see that get_task_output is used quite often, and now it also sends two LLM requests. Together these usually add 1.5-2s of time to the tool call, but I also just had a run where the second one took over 4s. I don't know why it was that slow this time but there will be randomness. So my question is just, is there anything we can do to speed this up?

- Can the two requests happen in parallel instead of one after the other?
- Do they have to both run every time? 
- Does the one that checks for errors have to run on a task that has a problem matcher?
- Maybe there is some local heuristic that we could use before running the one that looks for a question. Like it only runs if the last line has a question mark or includes some typical patterns
- Do you have telemetry that could tell us how long they took?
  - If you want to get the telemetry from the extension side that logs lots of things about each request already, I think we currently wouldn't have a way to differentiate this request from other API requests, but we could plumb some kind of identifier

[copilotLanguageModelWrapper_2.copilotmd](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22287857/copilotLanguageModelWrapper_2.copilotmd)
[copilotLanguageModelWrapper_d969dd71.copilotmd](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22287856/copilotLanguageModelWrapper_d969dd71.copilotmd)
[toolu_vrtx_01VFN9enXDVtfNa3Vf21EWXA__vscode-1757621338440.copilotmd](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22287866/toolu_vrtx_01VFN9enXDVtfNa3Vf21EWXA__vscode-1757621338440.copilotmd)

Probably you've already thought through some of this, but this is a really key tool and these are just some random things that came to mind while thinking about how to make the agent as fast as possible. Happy to brainstorm together sometime.

title: Unable to split standalone terminal window
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->

<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0 / Commit: f220831e
- OS Version: macOS 15.6.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode
2. Run "Terminal: Create New Terminal Window" via the Command Palette
3. Drag the new terminal window to a separate window if window merging enabled, as a result we now have the main window and the standalone terminal window
4. Run "Terminal: Split Terminal" via the Command Palette

### Expected
The standalone terminal window should be split to host new terminal pane.

### Happened
The new terminal pane is created in the editor area of the main window.

title: Agent Mode gets stuck on “Working...” when executing Python scripts in integrated terminal
body:

- Makes `onDidAccept` in the tree picker work (it previously no-op'd)

  re-retrieved after the MCP server is available, or tools don't show.

title: Copilot/Chat VSCode extensions: CSV files and folder context issues after recent updates
body: User reports issue with the GitHub Copilot and Copilot Chat VSCode extensions after their recent update - CSV files, including large single files (~16,500 lines), are not being fully read or referenced by Copilot when using 'Ask'. Only portions of the file are accessed, or the file is not found at all. - Copilot cannot read any objects (e.g., files) nested inside a folder, even if there is only a single object in the folder. - The 'Unknown variable type' error occurs when dragging any folder into the Copilot context, including folders with only a single 1-line text file. - Using '@workspace' as context still works, but this includes all files in the project, making targeted queries impossible. Previously, Copilot was able to reliably read/query any CSV file, regardless of size or nesting. No relevant details were found in recent release notes, documentation, or changelogs. Wondering if we are aware of any such changes **Environment:** - VSCode version: 1.103.1 - Copilot extension: 1.350.0 - Copilot Chat extension: 0.30.1

title: Gemini Code Assist Failing to Sync Logged In Session Across Open Windows

labels.name: *caused-by-extension
labels.description: Issue identified to be caused by an extension

body:
Type: Bug Have Gemini Code Assist open and logged in with multiple windows in folders. Close VSCode Reopen VSCode (potentially after computer reboot/update with VSCode/Update with Extension) You should see the Gemini Code Assist in the lower right corner in red with a prompt to login Click the button to login (copy the link and go to browser) Login Follow the localhost link to return to vscode 1 window may or may not be signed in then -All other windows will likely show some type of message about being unable to login/unable to connect to Gemini Code Assistant -New windows will likely show Gemini Code Assistant as signed in This is being noted from a usability perspective because for a number of use cases it is either problematic or not practical to reopen new windows for each project that was open to get sessions to sync. It is worth noting that restarting VSCode entirely generally ends up prompting for a login once again for Gemini Code Assist so you end up in a loop of logging back in forever. This has happened several different times for over a week now but I am not able to readily immediately reproduce the issue on every attempt. title: Window Size/Position Corruption and Freezing When Moving Between Monitors (Multi-Monitor Setup) Ao trocar de telas com Visual Studio Code
body:
Ao trocar de telas com Visual Studio Code
I am experiencing a consistent issue when using VS Code across two monitors. When I drag the VS Code window from one monitor to the other, the following problems occur:

Window Size/Position Corruption: The window often loses its remembered size and position. It appears either very small, off-screen, or at an incorrect, seemingly random size.

Application Freezing/Hanging: The window frequently freezes or becomes extremely unresponsive ("stutters") during or immediately after the move. It often stops redrawing and becomes unusable.

Workaround Required: The only reliable way to recover is to force-close VS Code (often through Task Manager) and reopen it, usually maximizing it on a single monitor to ensure it functions correctly.

This issue happens consistently and only with Visual Studio Code. All other applications on my system (browsers, Office suite, etc.) move between monitors without any problems.

Steps to Reproduce:
Open Visual Studio Code on Monitor 1.

Click and hold the title bar to drag the window to Monitor 2.

Release the mouse button.

Result: The window often appears at a corrupted size or position and/or becomes unresponsive.

Expected Result: The window should move smoothly to the second monitor and retain its size and position settings, behaving like any other standard Windows application.
System Information: Version: 1.104.0 (user setup)

title: Source Control panel is merged with Run and Debug
body:
Type: Bug After applying the latest update (1.104.0) I've noticed that the "Source Control" panel is missing from my activity bar. When I try to use the menus to View...Source Control, it takes me to the "Run and Debug" panel and merges the repository, source control, etc panels with the variables, watch, call stack panels that are typically dedicated to the debug panel. title: Clearing chat history via history button doesn't reflect in the welcome empty state view
body:
Repro:

1. Enable empty chat state history setting
2. Click the history button and delete past threads.

Expected - Chat empty state clears deleted threads
Actual - Chat empty state continues to show deleted threads
